title: Trump and Macron, a presidential bromance cartooned | The Economist

json.text: This week, France's president

Emmanuel Macron embarked
on a high-profile,
three-day state visit to Washington D.C.

Among all the pap and photo
ops, one clear story emerged:

Donald Trump and Emmanuel
Macron are in love.
Well, okay, not in love.

But considering all the
long embraces, hand holding,
longing looks, winks, smiles and giggles,

you can be forgiven for
jumping to that conclusion.

It was a classic French
seduction by Mr. Macron,

who had clearly won the grumpy
Mr. Trump over to his side.
His purpose was clear.
Mr. Macron is a dedicated internationalist
and advocate for liberal values.

To further these important
causes, he knows that America
needs to remain an engaged global leader.

The hope is that by winning
Mr. Trump's admiration,
you may win his support.
But the policy differences between
the two love birds are acute.

Gaining the fickle Mr. Trump's
affection and maintaining

his administration's commitments
to international treaties
are two quire different things.

There is one lasting image
from this week's bromance.

During an official photo
op, Mr. Trump turned

to the doting Mr. Macron, then
picked some supposed dandruff
off the shoulder of the French president.

It was a clear primal
dominance display by Mr. Trump.

Though the French are
masters of wit and charm,
it will remain a challenge for Mr. Macron

to smile and embrace the
mercurial American president.
